Posts.Content: On 6/17/2008 hennypen wrote: it seems like so many women put a lot of faith in these drugs like arimidex.  The percentage of women that they help is very low to give up your life to bone pain so bad that you cant take walks, or enjoy the things in life that you use to enjoy, and to think that they could cause other life long problems as well....that scares me even more than the cancer returning. I'm a 10 year survivor in Oct this year......I took Tamoxifin for 5 years and I'm taking Exemestane 25 mg.  I used to have the bone pain, but I found that exercise helped. I garden and don't watch TV.  You might try it.  I don't have bone pain anymore and I'm on my last bottle of Exemestane in my current clinical trial.  I don't know what my treatment will be once I finish this Phase III trial in August.   I did have bone pain for a couple of months but I have never allowed cancer to get me down.  I did Chemo/Radiation/Tamoxifin continued to work  and go to school.  The only problem I have encountered was with my need for life......my choices have led me to divorce a wonderful man and find another.  Hope I can stay happy and healthy......
Posts.Title: estrogen inhibitors

Posts.Content: Try long slow streching like yoga and glucosamine and chondroitin also really work.  I still have days when I get stiff and sore when getting out of bed, but, for the most part I think gardening with long slow streching has helped the most.  I also have taken part in a weight training class and building my muscles to support my bones.  Good luck and start slow but add 5 minutes each day...........hope you find the relief that I did.

Posts.Content: On 10/7/2007 HelenCM wrote: I just had a lumpectomy, and my nodes are clean. I have been reading messages about the horrible pain caused by the estrogen inhibitor drugs prescribed after radiation treatment. I wonder if any of you would recommend having chemo rather than the radiation/drug therapy? Sounds to me like the radiation/drug therapy process is long and horrible.....I know chemo is horrible, too, but for a shorter time. Any info you can share with me would be appreciated. I see my oncologist for the first time this week, and would like to be better informed. Thanks! I was diagnosed 10 years ago on 12/26/97.  I have done 2 types of chemo/six weeks of radiation and I am currently completing my second clinical trail using the estrogen inhibor drugs (5 years of tamoxifin and now my fourth and last year of exemstane).  I did research to find these clinical trails (3rd phase) because I wanted to kill the cancer in my body.  I now have two beautiful grandchildren (4 year old granddaughter and 2 year old grandson) and life is great.  I was 45 when diagnosed and I'm planning to retire within 2 years.  Please don't be afraid of any of these modern wonders.  Please do your research and find out the side effects and remember the side effects are for everyone who ever tried the drugs.....you won't have them all.  With the modern meds and wonderful doctors I have had, I'm here and planning to hang out for another 54 years.  Catch it early and kill it well...............dianimaln  livin' life
